abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Project Performance
            Assessment Report (PPAR) for four structural adjustment
            lending operations to Colombia from 2001 to 2005. The
            overall rating for all the four projects is rated as
            satisfactory in the Implementation Completion Report (ICR)
            rating, and also the performance of the Bank and the
            Borrower for all four projects is rated as satisfactory. The
            main lessons learned from this review are: (i) as noted in
            Independent Evaluation Group (IEG's) ICR Review of
            Fiscal and Institutional Adjustment Loan (FIAL III), project
            design needs to be clearly aligned with its development
            objectives in order to attain the latter. Even if the
            structural deficit of the central administration is
            "highly sensitive and political" as the ICR
            states, the magnitudes of these structural rigidities were
            such that they must be addressed if progress is to be made
            in achieving the substantial fiscal adjustment that is
            required for sustained macroeconomic stability; (ii) loans
            with large numbers of objectives and conditions, and
            involving too many institutions relative to the management
            capacity of the Government and the Bank itself, overtax the
            implementation capacity of both the Bank and the borrower
            and result in poor execution; (iii) the inclusion of
            objectives of widely different levels of priority and weak
            connection with the ultimate goals of the operations tends
            to obscure the degree of attainment of the latter; and (iv)
            success depends on the borrower's ownership of the
            objectives of the loan.

repnme.cdata!:
Colombia - Second Programmatic Fiscal and
            Institutional Structural Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Colombia Second Programmatic Fiscal
            and Institutional Structural Adjustment Loan Project had a
            satisfactory outcome, likely sustainability, substantial
            institutional development impact, overall satisfactory Bank
            and Borrower performances. The following lessonswere cited:
            1)  A high number of project components increases particular
            risks. This project had a total of 11 components in 4 broad
            groupings where the sheer breadth of topics, each with a
            specific reform plan, made the program particularly risky.
            The risks arise from the failure of a single component,
            which places the entire program at risk, since the
            assumption is that the program is a coherent
            "whole" that will lose integrity if parts are
            removed; high transaction costs due to the need to deal with
            multiple implementing agencies, retain multi-sector
            competency in the supervising team, and achieve enough
            analytical depth in each of the sectors; and losing a grasp
            of the overall program's coherence. This project was
            considered to be a fiscal adjustment operation and therefore
            subject to different standards. 2) Keep the number of policy
            actions reasonable. High numbers of policy actions increase
            the risk, add to transaction costs, and often do not add
            substance. Focus on results. That was done in the tax
            administration component, where the initial focus on a large
            set of specific actions (developing taxpayer registries,
            carrying out audits, improving information quality, and
            more) was substituted later on by two results indicators
            (evasion and efficiency). 3) Where the assessment indicates
            a relatively low probability of passing laws, the scope of
            the reform program should be narrowed to include only those
            elements under the Executive Branch's control. 4) Add a
            coherent and comprehensive package of technical assistance.
            5) Monitoring and evaluation arrangements must be ready
            up-front. 6) Task management from the field adds significant
            value; close and constant interaction with the client
            improves the probability of a successful outcome.

repnme.cdata!:
Colombia - Third Programmatic Fiscal and
            Institutional Structural Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Third Programmatic Fiscal and
            Institutional Structural Adjustment Loan Project within the
            program will focus primarily on the following key policy
            actions: a) acceleration of the phase-out of tax exemptions
            for profits of certain firms; b) increased revenues derived
            from improvements in tax administration of at least 0.3
            percent of GDP, between 2003 and 2004, while maintaining
            DIAN - Direccion de Impuestos y Aduanas Nacionales -
            administrative costs per peso collected, below 0.96 percent;
            c) submission of a new budget law to improve the overall
            budgeting framework, complementing the 2003 Fiscal
            Responsibility Law; d) further improvements in the royalty
            transfer system, including restructuring of the National
            Royalty Fund; e) implementation of the legal defense of the
            State policy; f) establishment of oversight bodies for both
            procurement and asset management; g) compliance with the
            pilot management contracts with ICBF - Institution
            Colombiano de Binestar Familiar - and SENA - Servicio
            Nacional de Aprendizaje; and, h) further progress in the
            monitoring system for the public sector reform process.
            Nonetheless, risks exist, namely: the uncertain political
            environment in the midst of a campaign for a presidential
            re-election; difficulty in controlling aggregate expenditure
            levels because of failure of key measures to contain them;
            institutional gaps that may remain after the public
            downsizing exercise, thus jeopardizing key roles, and
            responsibilities; external macroeconomic shocks; and, the
            current armed conflict.
